triples.name: Land use
triples.relevance: The paper examines effects of land use conversion from native prairie to cultivated cropland on microbial community networks.

triples.name: Soil microbiology
triples.relevance: The paper studies soil microbial communities and their network structure in response to land use changes.

triples.name: Complex network
triples.relevance: Network complexity metrics (connectivity, clustering coefficient, modularity) are central analytical tools in the paper.

triples.name: Tallgrass prairie
triples.relevance: The native tallgrass prairie serves as the reference ecosystem compared to cultivated cropland in the study.

triples.name: Crop
triples.relevance: Cultivation of crops is the land use conversion being examined and is the source of agricultural disturbance in the study.

triples.name: Tillage
triples.relevance: Conventional tillage is specifically examined as the agricultural management practice affecting soil microbial networks.

triples.name: Biodiversity
triples.relevance: The paper discusses reduced microbial biodiversity in cultivated lands as a trade-off against increased network stability.

triples.name: Ecological network
triples.relevance: The paper proposes that microbial ecological networks show increased complexity and stability under agricultural management.

triples.name: Ecological stability
triples.relevance: The paper proposes that agricultural disturbance leads to more robust and stable microbial networks despite biodiversity loss.

triples.name: Ecosystem ecology
triples.relevance: The paper examines ecosystem functions through the lens of soil microbial community structure and network dynamics.
